questions.question: What does cabotage refer to?

options.content: Domestic air services within a state

questions.question: The Convention signed by the states relating to damage caused by foreign aircraft to persons and property on the ground is:
The Convention on offences and other acts committed on board an aeroplane is:
Which of the following is an obligation of being an ICAO contracting state?

options.content: ICAO must be informed about all new flight crew licences and any suspended validity of such licences
ICAO must be informed about differences from the standards detailed in any of the annexes to the Chicago Convention
ICAO must approve the pricing of tickets on international airline connections
ICAO must be informed about changes to national regulations

questions.question: Which of the following annexes to the Chicago Convention contains the minimum specifications for the construction of aerodromes?
The ICAO annex containing the standards and recommended practices for Personnel Licensing is:
The aircraft commander may, when he/she has reasonable grounds to believe that a person has committed or is about to commit an offence against penal law on board the aircraft:

options.content: ask the crew to assist in restraining the person
order the passengers to assist the crew in restraining the person
deliver the person to the competent authority

questions.question: The international convention concerning the responsibilities of international air carriers (operators), for the carriage of passengers, baggage and freight is the:
The Rome convention and its later amendments deals with:

options.content: offences and other acts committed on board an aeroplane
damage caused by foreign aircraft to third parties on the ground
regulation of the transportation of dangerous goods
damage caused by any aircraft to third parties on the ground

questions.question: The Warsaw convention and its later amendments deals with:

options.content: regulation of the transportation of dangerous goods
operator’s licence for international scheduled operations
limitation of the Operator’s liability concerning passengers and goods transported

questions.question: The objectives of ICAO were defined by:
The annex to the Chicago convention which deals with the entry and departure of cargo and other articles on international flights is:
Which freedom of the air is applicable to a flight which wishes to land in a foreign state for technical reasons?
ICAO establishes:

options.content: aeronautical standards adopted by all states
proposals for aeronautical regulations in the form of 18 annexes
standards and recommended practices applied without exception by all states which are signatory to the Chicago Convention of 1944
standards and recommended practices for contracting states

questions.question: The first freedom of the air is:

options.content: The right to board passengers from the state where the aircraft is registered and fly to any other state
The right to over fly without landing
The right to land for a technical stop
The right to operate a commercial flight with passengers on board between two states

questions.question: The Convention which deals with offences against penal law is:
One of the main objectives of ICAO is to:

options.content: develop principles and techniques for international aviation
approve the ticket prices set by international airlines
approve new airlines operating turbine engine powered aircraft

questions.question: Which international convention established ICAO?
The standards contained in the annexes to the Chicago convention are to be considered:

options.content: binding upon all airlines operating international routes
binding for contracting states that have not notified ICAO about national differences
advice and guidance for the aviation legislation within contracting states

questions.question: Which body of ICAO finalizes the SARPs to be submitted for adoption?
The second freedom of the air is the:

options.content: right to operate a commercial passenger flight with passengers on board between two states
right to land in a foreign state for a technical stop
right to over fly a foreign state without landing

questions.question: Which annex contains information concerning Air Traffic Services?
To which passengers does EU Regulation 261/2004 apply?

options.content: To all passengers travelling on an EU registered aircraft wherever it may be operating
Those departing from an EU member state or travelling to an EU member state on an airline based in an EU member state
Only to those departing from an EU member state or travelling on an airline based in an EU member state
To all passengers who are citizens of an EU member state

questions.question: To which passengers does EU Regulation 261/2004 apply? Those who

options.content: arrived in time for check-in as indicated on the ticket or communication from the airline, or, if no time is so indicated, no less than 30 minutes prior to the scheduled departure time of the flight
arrived in time for check-in as indicated on the ticket or communication from the airline, or, if no time is so indicated, no less than 45 minutes prior to the scheduled departure time of the flight
arrived in time for check-in as indicated on the ticket or communication from the airline, or, if no time is so indicated, no less than 1 hour prior to the scheduled departure time of the flight
arrived in time for check-in as indicated on the ticket or communication from the airline, or, if no time is so indicated, no less than 2 hours prior to the scheduled departure time of the flight

questions.question: How much is the cash compensation given to a passenger under the EU Regulation 261/2004 travelling on a flight not within the EU of greater than 3500 km if the flight is cancelled?

How or where are airlines obliged to inform passengers stating that : “If you are denied boarding or if your flight is cancelled or delayed for at least two hours, ask at the check-in counter or boarding gate for the text stating your rights, particularly with regard to compensation and assistance.”

options.content: This is given verbally to individual passengers by airline staff at check-in
Printed on the airline ticket or the on-line receipt
Printed on a leaflet attached to the boarding pass
On a notice and on display at the passenger check-in counter

questions.question: The State of Design is to ensure that a continuing structural integrity programme, including information concerning corrosion control, is maintained in respect of aeroplanes:

options.content: with maximum certificated take-off mass less than 5700 kg
with maximum certificated take-off mass greater than 5700 kg
with maximum certificated take-off mass equal to 5700 kg
with maximum certificated take-off mass not more than 5700 kg

questions.question: The continuing validity of a Certificate of Airworthiness of an aircraft is subject to the laws of:

options.content: the State of Registration or the State of the Operator
the State of Registration and the State of Design

questions.question: When a Contracting State first enters on its register an aircraft and issues or validates a Certificate of Airworthiness, it shall inform:
Which document contains information concerning the flight limitations of the aircraft ?
What cannot be included in a registration mark?
What letters are prohibited for registration marks?

options.content: Any number referring to an ICAO document.

questions.question: Which of the following is not allowed in a registration mark?
What registration is disallowed because of possible confusion with distress/ urgency signals?
Which of the following is not permitted in the registration mark of an aircraft?

options.content: Any number identifying an ICAO document.

questions.question: Concerning aircraft registration, no combination of letters can be used which can be confused with distress codes, for example:
Which of the following registration marks would not be permitted?
Concerning aircraft registration markings, no combinations can be used if they can be mistaken for:

options.content: codes which are used for identification of ICAO documents.
letter combinations including the letter Q.
3 letter combinations which are used by international code of signals.
5 letter combinations which are used by international code of signals.

questions.question: According to Annex 7, the registration mark shall be letters, numbers or a combination of letters and numbers and shall be that assigned by:

options.content: the State of Registry or Common Mark Registering Authority.

questions.question: The common mark shall be selected from the series of symbols included in the radio call signs allocated:

options.content: to the State of Registry by ICAO.
to the State of Registry by the ITU.
to the State of the Operator.

questions.question: The height of the markings under the wings of a heavier than air aircraft shall be:

options.content: more than 40 cm but not more than 50 cm.

questions.question: The height of the markings on the fuselage (or equivalent surface) and on the vertical tail surface of a heavier than air aircraft shall be:

options.content: more than 20 cm but not more than 30 cm.

questions.question: According to JAR-FCL class ratings shall be established for single-pilot aeroplanes not requiring a type rating including:

options.content: all types of single-pilot, single-engine aeroplanes fitted with a turbojet engine.
microlights having fixed wings and moveable aerodynamic control surfaces acting in all three dimensions.
any other type of aeroplane if considered necessary.

questions.question: Which of the following is the privilege of the holder of a CPL(A)?

options.content: To act as PIC of any aeroplane engaged in operations other than commercial air transportation.
To act as PIC of any aeroplane engaged in commercial air transportation.
To act as PIC of any aircraft certificated for single-pilot operation other than commercial air transportation.
To act as co-pilot of any aircraft engaged in commercial air transport operations.

questions.question: What age do you need to be to exercise the privileges of a CPL licence?
When you are over 60 and the holder of an ATPL(A), how often are you required to have a medical examination?

options.content: The 12 month period reduces to 6 months.
The 24 month period reduces to 12 months.
The 6 month period reduces to 3 months.
The 9 month period reduces to 3 months.

questions.question: You can use simulator hours towards the 1500 hours required for an ATPL. How are simulator hours limited?

options.content: Maximum of 100, not more than 15 in a procedural flight trainer.
Maximum of 100, not more than 30 in a procedural flight trainer.
Maximum of 100, not more than 25 in a procedural flight trainer.
Maximum of 100, not more than 50 in a procedural flight trainer.

questions.question: What is the night flying hours requirement for an ATPL(A) licence?
One of the privileges of the holder of a CPL(A) is to:

options.content: act as co-pilot of aircraft in commercial air transport operations.
act as PIC of single engine aeroplanes in commercial air transport operations.
act as PIC of aeroplanes involved in operations other than commercial air transportation.

questions.question: Included in the requirements for 1500 hours, an ATPL(A) holder must have:

options.content: 500 hours multi-pilot operations in transport, commuter or equivalent category aircraft.
500 hours multi-pilot operations and 250 hours as PIC.
500 hours multi-pilot operations including up to 150 hours flight engineering time.
500 hours multi-pilot operations including 200 hours night time.

questions.question: When are you required to tell the authorities of an illness?

options.content: After the period of 21 days of illness has elapsed.
On the 21st day of the illness.

questions.question: To obtain a CPL(A), how many hours of cross-country flying are required?
What medical is required for the issue of a CPL(A)?
The holder of a pilot licence when acting as co-pilot under supervision of the PIC and performing the functions and duties of the PIC shall be entitled to be credited:

options.content: with 50% of the flight time towards the total time required for a higher grade of licence.
in full, but not more than 300 hrs towards the total time required for a higher grade of licence.
the flight time in full towards the total time required for a higher grade of licence.
the flight time in full towards the total time required for a higher grade of pilot licence according to the requirements of the licensing authority.

questions.question: For an ATPL(A), how many night hours are required?
How long would you have to spend in a clinic or hospital before you would have to inform the authorities?
When you are a newly qualified flying instructor you have to be supervised by a qualified flying instructor. When will the period of supervision cease?

options.content: Once you have passed a competency check.
When you have completed 100 hours instruction and sent 25 students solo.
When you have completed 25 hours instruction and sent 100 students solo.
When you have completed 100 hours solo.

questions.question: Between what ages can you exercise the privileges of an ATPL(A) on an unrestricted basis?
How long would a non-JAA licence be valid for if validated for use in a JAA state?

options.content: 12 months from the date of validation.
12 months providing the licence is still valid in the State of Issue.

questions.question: Which of the following correctly identifies the cross-country hours requirement for a CPL(A)?

options.content: 20 hours cross-country as PIC including a cross-country flight not less than 540 km (300 NM) in the course of which full stop landings are made at two different aerodromes.
25 hours including at least one flight of 2 hours duration covering at least 300 NM and to include 2 full stop landings.
10 hours solo with at least one flight over 300 NM with at least two full stop landings.

questions.question: What is the minimum age for a holder of a PPL?
What is the period of validity of a JAR-FCL class 2 medical?

options.content: 24 months until age 30, then 24 months until 50, then 12 months thereafter.
24 months until age 30, then 12 months until 50, then 6 months thereafter.
60 months until age 40, then 24 months until 50, then 12 months thereafter.
60 months until age 30, then 24 months until 50, then 12 months thereafter.

questions.question: A PPL(A) or Commercial licence holder, before taking his/her Instrument Rating, must have completed ................. hours of cross-country of which .............hours must be in an aeroplane ?
A PPL(A) holder shall demonstrate competence for an IR(A) in a………… aircraft type with ………………. .?
Of the 1500 hours required experience for an ATPL(A). ……… hours may be in a simulator but not more than ……. hours may be in a basic instrument trainer or basic procedure trainer.
Which of the following types of aircraft requires a type rating?

options.content: Each type of single-pilot multi-engine turbine.
Each type of micro-light with fixed wings and able to move its surfaces in three dimensions.
Each type of touring motor glider.

questions.question: To have an unrestricted FI(A) rating and to instruct for the issue of a CPL(A) or a PPL(A), you must have a CPL(A) or:

options.content: at least 250 hours as a pilot.
not less than 15 hours in the last 12 months on the relevant type.
at least 200 hours of flight instruction.
200 hours flight time of which not less than 150 hours is PIC.

questions.question: According to JAR-FCL, what classes of medical exist?
According to JAR-FCL, a single-engine class rating is valid for:

options.content: 2 years up to the age of 40 then 1 year thereafter.

questions.question: The validity of a multi-engine class rating or a type rating shall be 1 year from:

options.content: date of issue or the date of expiry if revalidated within the validity period.
date of application received by the authority.

questions.question: In order to carry out PPL(A) instruction you must:

options.content: hold a PPL(A) with instrument rating.
have passed the CPL theoretical knowledge exams and hold an FI(A) rating.

questions.question: For a pilot to hold an ATPL(A), the hours required are:

options.content: 500 PIC, or 300 PIC and 200 as co-pilot acting as PIC under supervision.
200 PIC, or 100 PIC and 100 as co-pilot acting as PIC under supervision.
250 PIC, or 150 PIC and 100 as co-pilot acting as PIC under supervision.
500 hrs as PIC under supervision or 250 hrs, either as PIC, or made up by not less than 70 hrs as PIC and the additional flight time as PIC under supervision.

questions.question: A pilot holding a CPL(A) can act as:

options.content: PIC of any aircraft in non-commercial aviation.
PIC in any single-engine aeroplane engaged in commercial aviation.
PIC of any single-pilot aeroplane engaged in commercial aviation.
PIC in any aircraft for which he/she is class/type rated engaged in noncommercial aviation.

questions.question: From what date is a medical certificate valid?

options.content: The date of the initial general medical examination.
The date the certificate is delivered to the pilot.
The date of the revalidation of the licence.

questions.question: Which of the following annexes of the Chicago Convention contains the minimum specification for a crew member’s licence to be recognized by Contracting States?
For the holder of a commercial pilot’s licence for single-pilot fixed-wing and helicopters who has attained the age of 40, the period between medical reports decreases from:
An applicant for an ATPL(A) for aircraft shall have at least:

options.content: 100 hours night flying purely as PIC.
75 hours night flying as PIC or as co-pilot.
100 hours night flying as PIC or as co-pilot.

questions.question: A CPL(A) applicant undergoing an integrated course of flight training shall have completed:

options.content: 150 hours flight time of which 5 hours may be instrument ground time.
200 hours flight time including 10 hours instrument ground time.

questions.question: If an applicant for a CPL(A) wishes to exercise the privileges of the licence at night, flight experience will include:

options.content: 5 hours of night flight including 3 take-offs and 5 landings as PIC.
5 hours of night flight including 5 take-offs and 5 landings as PIC.
5 hours of night flight including 5 take-offs and 5 landings as PIC or co-pilot.
5 hours of night flight including 3 take-offs and 3 landings as PIC or co-pilot.

questions.question: According to JAR-FCL, an instrument rating is valid for:

options.content: the period of validity of the licence.

questions.question: When acting as co-pilot of an aeroplane that requires a co-pilot, the pilot shall be entitled to credit not more than:

options.content: 40% of the co-pilot time towards the total flight time required for a higher grade of licence.
60% of the co-pilot time towards the total flight time required for a higher grade of licence.
100 hours of the co-pilot time towards the total flight time required for a higher grade of licence.
100% of the co-pilot time towards the total flight time required for a higher grade of licence.

questions.question: An applicant for a CPL(A) shall have completed in aeroplanes, not less than:

options.content: 200 hours of flight time including 70 hours as PIC.
150 hours of flight time including 100 hours as PIC.
200 hours of flight time or 150 hours if completed during an integrated course of approved training as a pilot of aeroplanes.
200 hours of flight time including 80 hours as PIC.

questions.question: The holders of pilot licences are required to inform the authority if, through illness, they are unable to undertake those functions to which the licence relates throughout a certain number of days. The number of days is:
The cross-country requirement for the issue of a CPL(A) is to include:

options.content: 20 hours cross country with one flight including 2 full stop landings over a total distance of 270 km (150 NM).
20 hours cross country with one flight including 2 full stop landings over a total distance of 540 km (300 NM).
10 hours cross country with one flight including 2 full stop landings over a total distance of 270 km (150 NM).
15 hours cross country with one flight including 2 full stop landings over a total distance of 540 km (300 NM).

questions.question: An applicant for a CPL(A) shall hold:

options.content: a current medical assessment to a level prescribed by the authority of the state of licence issue.

questions.question: How many synthetic flight trainer hours may be included by an applicant for an ATPL(A) as part of the 1500 hours necessary experience?

options.content: 100 hours of which not more than 15 hours have been completed in a flight procedures trainer or basic instrument trainer.
75 hours of which not more than 20 hours have been completed in a flight procedures trainer or basic instrument trainer.
100 hours of which not more than 25 hours have been completed in a flight procedures trainer or basic instrument trainer.
100 hours of which not more than 20 hours have been completed in a flight procedures trainer or basic instrument trainer.

questions.question: According to JAR-FCL, an applicant for an IR(A) shall hold a PPL(A) with a night qualification, or a CPL(A), and have completed at least 50 hours:

options.content: instructional time as student PIC of aeroplanes or helicopters of which at least 10 hours is to be in aeroplanes.
cross-country time as PIC of aeroplanes or helicopters of which at least 10 hours is to be in aeroplanes.
cross-country time as a pilot of aeroplanes or helicopters of which at least 10 hours is to be in aeroplanes.
instructional time as student PIC of aeroplanes.

questions.question: For which of the following are type ratings established?

options.content: Each type of single-pilot multi-engine aeroplane fitted with turbine engines.
Any type of aircraft whenever considered necessary by the authority.
All the above answers are correct.

questions.question: According to JAR-FCL, establishment of separate type rating for aeroplanes will be assessed on the basis of three criteria. One of these criteria is that the aeroplane has:

options.content: handling characteristics that require the use of more than one crew member.
a certificate of airworthiness issued by a non-JAA state.
a certificate of airworthiness issued by the manufacturer.
handling characteristics that require additional flying or simulator training.

questions.question: Which annex to the Chicago Convention contains minimum specifications for a crew licence to have international validity?
A type rating is applicable to:

options.content: an aeroplane requiring a certificate of airworthiness.
an aeroplane with a certificate of airworthiness issued by the state of licence issue.
an aeroplane that requires multi-pilot operation.
an aeroplane that requires additional skills training.

questions.question: According to JAR-FCL, recognized instructor categories are:

options.content: FI(A); TRI(A); CRI(A); IRI(A); MCCI(A) and SFI(A) only.

questions.question: When a state renders valid a licence issued by another Contracting State, as an alternative to issuance of its own licence, the period of validity shall:

options.content: not extend beyond 15 days after the validity of the licence.
not extend beyond the period of validity of the licence.
be at the discretion of the validating state.
be at the discretion of ICAO.

questions.question: An applicant for a JAR-FCL ATPL(A) has to demonstrate the ability to pilot:

options.content: multi-crew aircraft requiring a Flight Engineer.
night flights with passengers on board.

questions.question: A pilot is not to operate an aircraft as PIC or co-pilot in CAT or carry passengers unless he/she has carried out at least:

options.content: 5 take-offs and landings in the preceding 90 days
3 take-offs, approaches and landings in the preceding 90 days
5 take-offs, approaches and landings in the preceding 90 days
5 take-offs, approaches and landings in the preceding 60 days

questions.question: A pilot is not to operate an aircraft as PIC at night in CAT or carry passengers at night unless he/she has carried out at least:

options.content: 1 take-off, approach and landing at night in the preceding 90 days or holds an Instrument Rating
5 take-offs, approaches and landings at night in the preceding 90 days or holds an Instrument Rating
3 take-offs, approaches and landings at night in the preceding 90 days or holds an Instrument Rating
3 take-offs, approaches and landings at night in the preceding 60 days or holds an Instrument Rating

questions.question: What does cabotage refer to?

options.content: Domestic air services within a state

questions.question: The Convention signed by the states relating to damage caused by foreign aircraft,to persons and property on the ground is
What does cabotage refer to?

options.content: Domestic air services within a state

questions.question: The Convention signed by the states relating to damage caused by foreign aircraft,to persons and property on the ground is
